Title: The growth and impact of the internet on the users: A research on Internet phenomena in Indonesia in 2016
Source title: Proceedings - 2017 10th International Conference on Human System Interactions, HSI 2017
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center (CBDC), Industrial Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Character Building Development Center (CBDC), Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Witono, P.H., Character Building Development Center (CBDC), Industrial Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Lakonawa, P., Character Building Development Center (CBDC), Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This work is motivated by the phenomenon of sophistication of Internet technology which nowadays is rapidly evolving in Indonesia. Indonesia is a developing country which has a great enthusiasm for Internet technology. In history, the Indonesian government began developing the Internet in the early 1980s at the state universities in Indonesia. Internet started to become popular since the collapse of the Suharto regime in 1998. Until the end, the Internet became a tool used by many college students to perform a political movement. Since then, the Indonesian community began to recognize the internet-based activity. However, the progress of the Internet in Indonesia also has an impact on behavior change for young generation. This article shows to the government, parents and internet users in Indonesia how shall we manage the advancement of the Internet. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Behavior; Generation; Internet; Networking; Online; Social media
Index Keywords: Developing countries; Students; Behavior; Generation; Networking; Online; Social media; Internet
Funding Text 1: This work was supported in part by Bina Nusantara University under BINUS Research Grant.

Authors: Gea A.A., Tampubolon S.M., Lakonawa P.
Title: Developing positive multicultural attitudes in student organization
Authors with affiliations: Gea, A.A., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Tampubolon, S.M., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Lakonawa, P., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The multicultural mindset and attitude have become compulsory requirements for the professionals in this globalized era of today. For that reason education should help develop students’ skills in this aspect. To portray how student organization fosters the skills this research article is conducted. Using the qualitative research method, it analyzes the management of multiculturalism at BINUS Industrial and Information Business Club (BIIBC). Through interviews, questionnaires and observations, the study will examine and explore how BIIBC manage and develop the multicultural attitude within the organization. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cultural diversity; Models of multiculturalism; Multicultural attitude; Multicultural management; Multiculturalism
References: Hartmann, D., Gerteis, J., (2005) Sociological Theory, 23, p. 2; Kapukaya, K., (2010) Journal of Cultural Studies, 8, p. 1; Maxwell, Y., (2011) Canadian Ethnic Studies, p. 43; Munusamy, V.P., (2008) International Management, p. 25; Naseem, M.A., (2011) Canadian Issues, p. 9; Sayles-Hannon, S.J., (2008) In Search of Multiculturalism: Uprooting ‘Whiteness’ in Curriculum Design and Pedagogical Strategies, 66p. , Texas Woman’s University; Song, S., (2005) The American Political Science Review, 99, p. 4; Suparlan, P., (2001) Kesetaraan Warga Dan Hak Budaya Komuniti Dalam Masyarakat Majemuk Indonesia, , Andalas University, Padang

Title: Enhancing student’s time management skills in the pursuit of professional character: A research on students at double degree program
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Martoredjo, N.T., Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Lakonawa, P., Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Character building is one of the most significant parts of the efforts to develop human resources quality in the view of the present and future global career competition. Among all characters that are integral to the professional attitude is the ability to manage time ideally which is known as time management skills. This skill is so much decisive for the promotion of one’s career that requires the students to build a good habit of effective time management. This research attempts to describe how the above average level students (with GPA above 2.8) of double degree program manage their time. By using the method of direct observation and interviews, the research found that their academic achievement is so much determined by their ability to manage time. Their good time management habit significantly constitutes their professional attitude which would define their career progress in the future. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
References: Covey, S.R., (1998) The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, , Binarupa Aksara, Jakarta; de Janasz, S.C., (2009) Interpersonal Skills in Organizations, , McGraw Hill, Boston; Claessens, J.C.B., Van Eerde, W., Rutte, G.C., Roe, R., A Review of Time Management Literatur (2007) Personnel Review, 36, pp. 255-276; Macan, T.H., Shahani, C., Dipboye, R.L., Phillips, A.P., (1990) Journal of Educational Psychology, 82, p. 760; Yager, J., (2004) Creative Time Management, , Bhuana Ilmu Populer, Jakarta; Hamzah, A.R., Lucky, E.O., Joarder, M.H., Time Management, External Motivation, and Students’ Academic Performance: Evidence from a Malaysian Public University (2014) Asian Social Science, 10, pp. 55-63; Kirillov, A.V., Tanatova, D.K., Vinichenko, M.V., Makushkin, S.A., Theory and Practice of Time-Management in Education (2015) Asian Social Science, 11, pp. 193-204; Yukselturk, E., Bulut, S., Predictors for Student Success in an Online Course (2007) Educational Technology and Society, 10, pp. 71-83; Lay, H.C., Schouwenburg, H., (1993) Journal of Social Behavior and Personality, 8, p. 647

Title: Promoting social justice through inclusive languages of God in christian theologies
Authors with affiliations: Lakonawa, P., Binus University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: What is the right way to speak about God? This question is very important because the languages about God are foundations of a community of faith. In the languages about God, people put the primary symbol of the whole religious system. Hence the ways in which a community of faith shapes languages about God implicitly represents what it takes to be the highest good. Such speaking, in turn, powerfully molds the identity of the community and directs its praxis. This article will discuss a need for inclusive languages of God. The author shares the suggestion of Elizabeth Schüssler Fiorenza that those who are excluded from institutions of knowledge and power must be allowed to participate in articulating their perceptions and imaginations as to promote a more just, egalitarian and inclusive society. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers.
Author Keywords: Feminist theology; Languages about god; Patriarchy
References: Faria, S., On Language and Sexism (1987) Jeevadhara, pp. 33-34. , January; McFague, S., (1983) Metaphorical Theology: Models of God in Religious Language, 6p. , SCM Press Ltd, London; McFague, S., (1983) Metaphorical Theology: Models of God in Religious Language, pp. 7-9. , SCM Press Ltd, London; Johnson, E.A., (1992) She Who Is: The Mystery of God in Feminist Theological Discourse, 38p. , Crossroad, New York; Chopp, R.S., (1989) The Power to Speak: Feminism, Language, God, Crossroad, 1p. , New York; Reuther, R.R., (1983) Sexism and God-Talk: Toward a Feminist Theology, 12p. , Beacon, Boston; Reuther, R.R., (1983) Sexism and God-Talk: Toward a Feminist Theology, pp. 18-19. , Beacon, Boston; Reuther, R.R., (1983) Sexism and God-Talk: Toward a Feminist Theology, 13p. , Beacon, Boston; Johnson, E.A., (1988) Chicago Studies, 27, p. 130; Johnson, E.A., (1992) She Who Is: The Mystery of God in Feminist Theological Discourse, 76p. , Crossroad, New York; Johnson, E.A., (1988) Chicago Studies, 27, p. 132; Vatican II's, Pastoral Constitution on the Church in the Modern World, , Gaudium et Spes #29; Catechism of the Catholic Church no. 42; Reuther, R.R., (1983) Sexism and God-Talk: Toward a Feminist Theology, 20p. , Beacon, Boston; Schmidt, G.R., (1982) Worship, 56, p. 117
